header.title: THE GAME OF TAROTS and STUDY ON THE TAROTS, and on the Divination by the Cards of the Tarots
authors: M. Le C. de M. (Louis Raphaël Lucrèce de Fayolle, the Comte de Mellet)
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Tarot History, Divination

central_thesis: Court de Gébelin posits that the Tarot is an ancient Egyptian "Book of Thoth" (Ta-Rosh), a repository of esoteric wisdom encoding philosophical, religious, and political allegories, which survived through time as a game. The Comte de Mellet's essay further elaborates on this Egyptian origin, links the 22 Trumps to Hebrew letters, and outlines a specific practical system for Tarot divination, framing it as a sacred science for interpreting destiny.

structure_content.chapter_title: THE GAME OF TAROTS (by Antoine Court de Gébelin)
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the Tarot as a unique surviving 'Egyptian book' composed of 77 or 78 cards, filled with profound allegories. Court de Gébelin meticulously deciphers the symbolic meanings of the 22 Major Arcana (Atouts), linking them to Egyptian deities (Isis, Osiris, Typhon), cardinal virtues, and human conditions. He establishes the four suits (Sword, Cup, Baton, Coin) as representations of Egyptian social classes (Sovereign/Military, Clergy, Agriculture, Trade) and emphasizes the sacred significance of the number seven in the deck's structure. The text also includes a description of how Tarots were played as a game and explores its supposed connections to political geography, a Chinese monument, and medieval tournaments, arguing that modern Spanish and French playing cards are degraded imitations of this ancient system. He asserts the Fool's placement at the head of the trumps and its connection to the 22 Hebrew letters.

structure_content.chapter_title: STUDY ON THE TAROTS, and on the Divination by the Cards of the Tarots (by M. Le C. de M.)
structure_content.summary: This essay explicitly identifies the Tarot as the 'Book of Thoth' (Ta-Rosh), an ancient Egyptian cosmogony. M. Le C. de M. presents an alternative ordering of the trumps, starting with the World (XXI) and ending with the Fool (zero), which he considers the 'zero of magic calculations.' He divides the trumps into three 'Ages' (Gold, Silver, Iron) and offers detailed allegorical and mythological interpretations for each, reinforcing their Egyptian origins. The core of this section is a comprehensive practical system for divination, explaining how ancient Egyptian Magi and priests would have used these symbolic cards to consult the Fates. It details the steps of the divination ritual, the specific meanings of the suits and trump cards (including connections to Spanish card names and their Egyptian equivalents), and how to interpret card combinations for prognostication.

key_concepts.definition: According to Court de Gébelin, the Tarot is an ancient Egyptian 'book' of esoteric wisdom, meaning 'Royal Path of Life.' It is a collection of allegorical images encoding profound philosophical, religious, and political doctrines, believed to have survived from antiquity.

The 22 principal cards of the Tarot deck, interpreted as allegorical representations of leaders, cardinal virtues, celestial bodies (Sun, Moon, Dog Star), deities (Osiris, Typhon), and fundamental human conditions and life events. These are linked to the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet.

The four minor suits of the Tarot, symbolically representing the four social classes of ancient Egypt: Sword (Sovereign/Military), Cup (Clergy/Priesthood), Baton (Agriculture), and Coin (Trade). In divination, they correspond to different aspects of fortune, happiness, misfortune, and indifference.

A unique card in the Tarot deck, sometimes placed at the head of the trumps, representing folly or insignificance in Court de Gébelin's system. For M. Le C. de M., it is the 'zero of magic calculations,' a card without inherent power but capable of increasing the value of other cards it precedes in a divinatory sequence, and associated with the Hebrew letter Tau.

The specific identification of the Tarot by M. Le C. de M. as an ancient Egyptian cosmogony and historical record, a 'book' composed of images that convey the doctrines and history of Thoth or Mercury.

The system of symbolic images depicted on Tarot cards, believed to be a form of sacred Egyptian writing that transmits profound doctrines and historical narratives, which, when arranged, form 'sentences of Destiny.'

A foundational numerical principle in the Tarot's structure, reflecting its supposed Egyptian origin. Each suit effectively contains two sets of seven cards (court cards and pip cards up to X), and the Atouts are described as 'three times seven,' totaling 77 cards (plus the Fool). This number governed the arrangement of 'all sciences' for the Egyptians.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined by M. Le C. de M. is a method of Tarot divination ('consulting the Fates') using a 78-card deck. It aims to reveal future events or insights into destiny by arranging chosen cards into a 'hieroglyphic sentence.' This system assigns specific numerical values, allegorical meanings, and contextual interpretations to individual cards and combinations, with the Fool acting as a special 'zero' card that modifies the values of others.
tools: A complete 78-card Tarot deck, consisting of 22 Major Arcana (Atouts) and 56 Minor Arcana divided into four suits (Sword, Cup, Baton, Coin).
rituals: **Preparation:** Two participants are involved: one consulting, one divining. The 22 Trumps (letter cards) are conceptually separated from the four suits for counting purposes.
**Shuffling & Cutting:** The deck is shuffled, and each participant performs a cut on the other's cards.

**Dealing & Counting (First Pass):** Cards are dealt face-down. The diviner counts up to the number fourteen. If a suit card appears in its 'natural place' (its number aligns with the count or a specific rule), it is set aside along with the corresponding Trump card, which is placed above it. This action ensures the 'book of Destiny' remains whole.
**Repetition (Second & Third Passes):** The remaining cards are remixed, cut, and the dealing and counting process is repeated twice more for a total of three passes.
**Arrangement:** All cards that were set aside during the three passes are arranged in the exact order they were drawn, forming a 'hieroglyphic sentence.'

**Interpretation:** The diviner deciphers this sentence by combining the numerical values, allegorical meanings, and contextual significances of the cards. Court cards represent individuals. Trumps (Atouts) have primary allegorical meanings and specific numerical values (e.g., Sun=happiness, Fortune=rule, Death=reaping). Suit cards have general divinatory associations (Cups/Hearts=happiness, Coins/Clubs=fortune, Swords/Spades=misfortune, Batons/Diamonds=indifference). The Fool, as 'zero of magic calculations,' has no inherent numerical value but 'puts the Sun to the hundreds,' implying it significantly magnifies the influence of cards it precedes or combines with in numerical calculations. Card combinations modify meanings (e.g., Spades with Clubs reduces misfortune).
**Outcome:** The final interpretation predicts happiness or misfortune, detailing associated events and their magnitude based on card strength and surrounding cards.

relevant_quotes.text: If one proceeded to announce that there is still nowadays a work of the former Egyptians, one of their books that escaped the flames that devoured their superb libraries, and which contains their purest doctrines on interesting subjects, everyone who heard, undoubtedly, would hasten to study such an invaluable book, such a marvel. [...] This book is in a word the game of Tarots...

Court de Gébelin's essay is noteworthy for establishing the Tarot as a repository of esoteric wisdom, for placing its origins in ancient Egypt, for linking the dissemination of the Tarot throughout Europe with the Gypsies, for alluding to the connection between the 22 trumps and 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet, and for placing the Fool firmly at the head of the trumps, rather than at their end, its previous traditional location.
The name of this game is pure Egyptian: it is composed of the word Tar, which means way, path; and of the word Ro, Ros, Rog, which means king, royal. It is, literally, the Royal Path of Life.
Lastly, there is a twenty-second card without number as without power, but which increases the value of that which it precedes; it is the zero of magic calculations: it is called the Fool.

Whatever happiness or misfortune is predicted by each one of them, must be combined with what the card announces that corresponds to them, in the same way that their greater or lesser power is determined by the number of this same card, multiplied by that which characterizes the letter. And for this reason the Fool which does not produce anything, is without number; it is, as we have said, the zero of this calculation.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is a cornerstone in the history of esoteric Tarot, despite its historical inaccuracies (e.g., Egyptian origin, Gypsy dissemination), as acknowledged by the translator. Court de Gébelin's work profoundly shifted Tarot's perception from a mere game to a vehicle of ancient wisdom, directly inspiring subsequent occultists like Eliphas Lévi, the Golden Dawn, and A.E. Waite. The explicit (Comte de Mellet) or alluded (Gébelin) connection between the 22 Trumps and the Hebrew alphabet is crucial for the development of Qabalistic Tarot. M. Le C. de M.'s detailed account of a practical divination system, including specific card meanings and ritualistic steps, provides a rare glimpse into early formalized Tarot practices and their conceptual framework, predating many modern systems.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience comprises scholars and educated individuals interested in antiquities, cultural history, and the philosophical underpinnings of ancient civilizations. The detailed allegorical interpretations and historical conjectures cater to this academic curiosity. However, M. Le C. de M.'s explicit 'Application of this game to divination' and step-by-step 'Way in which one proceeds to consult the Fates' clearly also target individuals seeking practical methods for prognostication and those with a developing interest in occult or esoteric practices, offering a structured 'system of destiny' for magical application.
